hobby.message: Analog photography survive another day in Stenograd?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: Yeah. As steady as the servers let us be.
Been spending some time flying drones. Clears the head.
Kept out of the way when chaos hit last week.
Just stayed low, nothing special.
I’m holding up. Drone flying keeps things balanced.
Spent last week near Sector 6—good for focus, less eyes.
That manual week? Fewer patrols meant less hassle.
Hard to say who else is out there now.
Just kept my flight brief.
More or less. Long shifts, then drone runs when I get clear.
FPV flying runs are how I reset.
Sector 6’s been busier since all that Council mess.
Signals crossed last week—whole patch felt jumpy.
The blackout gave us some freedom, but not sure it’s safe.
I still keep to myself out there.
Mostly steady. Flying FPV drones—freestyle, real first-person sight—keeps me together.
Rail yards on the city edge, usually quiet, I fly there.
Lately, after Halden’s death, everyone’s tense—even at off-grid spots.
Manual management week was messy. Patrols backed off, and fliers came out.
Had interference on my last run—never seen chatter that heavy.
Some were trading routes, bypassing network gaps.
Felt almost normal, just risky.
I’m holding steady now. Those off-grid drone flights pretty much saved my sanity.
Started years ago, when the city was less...monitored.
With Halden gone and those journal rumors, my spot near Sector 6 got crowded fast.
Manual week, no BCI—people showed up, running mesh tests and packet swaps.
Signals were messy, but the freedom felt real for a change.
FPV freestyle’s more than a hobby—teaches control, patience, timing.
Usually I fly alone. Last week, it felt like community, just for a minute.
Still watching my back—my score dipped after, but worth it.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Still flying drones sometimes.
Mostly after work, keeps my head clear.
Not many good spots left these days.
Security checks make it harder now.
Saw more people out lately, but I keep to myself.
FPV's still my thing, yeah.
Nice to have some open air, away from screens.
Sector 6 was crowded last week, which is weird.
Ever since that Council journal rumor, feels less safe.
Security bots are much more common now.
I keep a low profile, just in case.
Yeah, drones help me focus more than any, let's say, official therapy.
Took mine to the rail yards after the BCI glitches started.
Never seen so many pilots in one place. It's attracting attention.
Interference made flying hell—all those random signals.
Security drones were circling, probably tracking new unofficial networks.
With the manual district week, everyone wanted off-grid comms.
It was almost like a hidden meetup, but way edgier.
Definitely still flying. Actually had a wild run during that BCI blackout week.
Sector 6 yards were full of unofficial flyers, all dodging extra surveillance.
We were all riding the wave when the scoring paused. Total anonymity.
Saw some building mesh links, guessing they want more private nets.
Interference was brutal—half my telemetry was scrambled by pirate chatter.
Security bots were relentless, but we all just worked around them.
For a short time, it felt freer, not as controlled.
Honestly, kind of reminded me why I like old tech.
Yeah, FPV drones are still it for me. Been my escape since before my brother disappeared.
Last week, with the BCI off, the whole city shifted—people out flying like it was old times.
It wasn't just for fun—lots were trading blackout codes, building mesh nets.
Sector 6 was buzzing with encrypted traffic and people talking face-to-face for once.
I managed to fly through spots that would've triggered lockdown just a month ago.
Everyone felt anonymous, like we could exist outside the score, even if only for an hour.
I ran silent, barely used OSD—habit from wiping my own logs after what happened to my brother.
Strange seeing so many 'invisible' folks appear again—felt risky but real.
Honestly, it made me wonder what freedom would be like without the index at all.
